CeO2 with varied doping transition metal was investigated to understand the oxygen storage capacity and oxygen release property of CeO2-based catalysts for toluene combustion. The order of catalytic activity was as follows: CuCeO x ≈ CoCeO x > MnCeO x > FeCeO x > NiCeO x > ZrCeO x > CeO2. Kinetic studies showed that the reaction on CuCeO x proceed via an MvK mechanism and the oxygen of catalyst was crucial factor for the toluene combustion. H2-TPR and XPS showed the addition of transition metal to CeO2 could modify the surface lattice oxygen. Moreover, the oxygen storage capacity and oxygen release properties showed the transition metal additive not only change the amount of oxygen, but also affect the oxygen mobility. A linear relationship was observed between the catalytic activity and oxygen storage capacity. Diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy showed the toluene first adsorbed on the surface of catalyst, and then reacted with oxygen of catalyst to form benzyl, benzoate and benzyl carbonate species. All these results provided a new strategy to develop high performance catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Toluene combustion Oxygen storage capacity Oxygen mobility In situ DRIFTS Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ceria-based materials have been widely used as oxygen storage component in automotive catalysts, due to its high oxygen storage capacity (OSC) and redox properties. Several methods have been devoted to change the oxygen activation and migration on the OSC component of catalyst via manipulating the structural defects. The common method was to control the morphology of CeO2 with different morphologies, in order to obtain different exposed surfaces of {001} and {110} [1] or surface lattice oxygen [2]. Moreover, the addition of transition metal to CeO2 could affect Ce coordination shell and the Ce–O bond length, thus varying the oxygen storage capacity [3]. These promotional effect on oxygen storage and release provide an alternative method for developing catalysts for several oxidation reactions, such as soot combustion [4], methane combustion and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) combustion [5]. VOCs are one of the main pollutants of air pollution, causing significant hazards to the natural environment and human health. Toluene, as a typical VOCs, is commonly used as a model molecule for the development of VOCs abatement catalysts [6]. The redox properties and oxygen storage capacity of CeO2 make it an excellent catalyst or catalyst support for the catalytic combustion of toluene. The activity of catalytic combustion of toluene is highly sensitive to the oxygen storage and oxygen migration of CeO2. However, the oxygen storage and transport was decided by the two kinds of defect, including intrinsic defects and extrinsic defects [7]. The intrinsic defects are the oxygen vacancies which are from reduced ceria itself. However, the extrinsic defects are the oxygen vacancies which are from the charge compensation effect when a lower valence dopants substituted the Ce position of the CeO2 lattice. These charge compensation are influenced by many factors, such as valence state, ionic radius and the formation of enthalpy of varied metal-oxygen bond [4,8]. Si et al. [9] investigated the doping effects of ZrO2 into CeO2 on the oxygen storage capacity. It was found that smaller Zr4+ ion could substitute the position of Ce4+, which resulted in positive effect on the microstrain, and thus enhanced OSC. Moreover, the OSC of CeO2-ZrO2 samples was in a linear relationship with microstrain. Myung et al. [10] demonstrated that the introduction of aliovalent metal cations in the CeO2 could significantly increase the OSC, which was in relation with ionic radius and redox couple potential. The enhanced OSC was observed on the lower ionic radius and lower redox potential. The smaller valence dopant could decrease the lattice parameters, which would induce the lattice distortion, and thus increase the reducibility of ceria. Balducci et al. [11] study the reduction process of CeO2−MOx via a computer simulation study. It was found that divalent dopants resulted in more promotional effect on the reduction of Ce4+/Ce3+, compared with trivalent dopants, because each divalent dopant could induce two oxygen vacancies. Moreover, the larger ionic size dopant is more favorable for the reduction of Ce4+/Ce3+, which was due to the effective in relieving greater relaxation or elastic strain associated with forming larger Ce3+ species. Kehoe et al. [12] demonstrated that the promotional effects on the OSC of ceria with varied dopants are not only depended on the size of dopant ions, but also on the electronic structure of the dopants. For transition metal dopants, crystal field splitting effect became more important and should be considered for the variation of electronic structure requirement of dopants. When a transition metal substituted the cubic Ce lattice site, square planar and octahedral crystal field splitting is more adopted on the d [8] ion. Whereas, d [9] ion is more favorable for Jahn-Teller distorted octahedral splitting. The different crystal field effect was decided by the minimum energy configuration of a doped system. However, the underlying mechanism of oxygen storage and release capacity improvement with transition-metal doped CeO2 has not been thoroughly investigated. Herein, MCeO x (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) was prepared by doping transition metals into CeO2 for catalytic combustion of toluene. The structure of MCeO x was characterized by N2-physisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR).The kinetic data were fitted with eight different kinetic models and MCeO x proceed via MvK mechanism. The activation energy of CeO2 oxygen mobility by transition metal doping was determined by investigating the variation of OSC for MCeO x at different temperatures. The reaction pathway of toluene catalytic combustion by MCeO x was analyzed by in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). A linear relationship between MCeO x toluene catalytic combustion activity and OSC was observed, providing a basis understanding for the catalytic combustion of VOCs via manipulating the mobility of oxygen. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The ethanol, cerium oxide nanoparticles (20–50 nm), ferric nitrate hydrate, manganese nitrate, copper nitrate, cerium nitrate hexahydrate, cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, nickel nitrate hexahydrate, zirconium nitrate pentahydrate, toluene used in the experiment were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Chemical Technology Co. Ltd. and the N2, O2, Ar were purchased from Xi'an Tenglong Chemical Co. Ltd. All reagents were analytical grade and used as received without additional purification or treatment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation MCeO x (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) was prepared via wet impregnation of CeO2 with an aqueous solution of M(NO3) x with vigorous stirring, followed by drying at 60 °C in a rotary evaporator and calcination in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 3 h. The composition of these samples were measured by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy. The metal loading of all these samples was 5 wt%. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystal structures of the samples were analyzed by Shimadzu XRD-6100 X-ray diffraction (XRD) equipped with a Cu Kα (λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation source at 40 kV and 30 mA. The 2θ angles were scanned from 10 to 80° with a step size of 0.017° and a scan speed of 7°/min. For obtaining the specific surface area and pore structure of the catalysts, the catalysts were analyzed by constant temperature and variable pressure adsorption/desorption tests with N2 as the adsorbent under −196 °C liquid nitrogen using a BELSORP-Max (MicrotracBEL, Japan) physical adsorptive instrument. The specific surface area was determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, the pore size distribution was obtained by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Oxygen storage/release measurements were carried out using NETZSCH-STA449F5 thermal gravimetric analyzer under cyclic oxidizing (20 vol% O2 + Ar) and reducing (5 vol% H2 + Ar) atmospheres at different temperatures (200, 250, 300, 350, 400 °C). Prior to each test, the samples were first pretreated at 400 °C in a flowing stream of 20 vol% O2 + Ar for 30 min. The oxygen storage capacity (OSC), oxygen release rate (ORR) and oxygen storage rate (OSR) were calculated via the following equations: (1) OSC ( μ mol / g ) = − w o x i − r e d w c a t × n O (2) ORR ( μ mol / ( g · s ) ) = − DT G m a x − r e d w c a t × n O (3) OSR ( μ mol / ( g · s ) ) = − DT G m a x − o x i w c a t × n O Where woxi-red denotes the weight difference between oxidizing and reducing atmosphere; wcat denotes the weight of catalyst; nO denotes atomic weight of oxygen; DTG max-red denotes maximum slop of the weight loss during reducing atmosphere; DTG max- oxi denotes maximum slop of the weight loss during oxidizing atmosphere. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was measured on a Kratos AXIS Ultra-DLD electron spectrometer with an Al Kα excitation source. The binding energy of each element was calibrated via the adventitious carbon (284.6 eV). Temperature programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) was carried out in a home-made equipment in a flowing atmospheres containing 5 vol% H2 + Ar from 100 °C to 800 °C with a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min. Prior to H2-TPR experiment, the sample was pretreated in 20 vol% O2 + Ar at 400 °C for 1 h. The concentrations of effluent gases were analyzed by a mass spectrometer (TILON GRP Technology Limited, LC-D200M). Temperature programmed desorption of O2 (O2-TPD) experiments were carried out in a flowing Ar (40 mL/min) from 100 °C to 800 °C with a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min. The procedure of pretreatment in O2-TPD was same as that in H2-TPR. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was obtained by accumulating 32 scans on a Nicolet iS50 Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer with a scanning range of 650 to 4000 cm−1 and a resolution of 4 cm−1. The spectrometer was equipped with a DRIFTS cell containing ZnSe windows and a highly sensitive MCT-A detector cooled by liquid N2. The temperature was controlled by a pike temperature module and the feed gas was controlled by a mass flow controller. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurement The catalytic performance and kinetic studies of toluene combustion was evaluated in a fixed bed plug-flow quartz reactor (4 mm i.d.). In each experiment, 100 mg sample (40–60 mesh) with 300 mg quartz sands (40–60 mesh) was placed into the reactor with quartz wool supported. The overall flow of feed gas is 40 mL/min, which corresponds to a gas hourly space velocity of 24,000 mL·g −1·h −1. Maintaining a constant toluene concentration of 1000 ppm and varying the flow rate of oxygen to a range of 2 vol%, 5 vol%, 10 vol%, 15 vol%, 20 vol% for obtaining the influence of oxygen concentration on the toluene conversion rate. Alternatively, maintaining a constant oxygen concentration (20 vol% O2) and varying the flow rate of the toluene gas line to a range of 500, 1000, 2000, 3000, 4000 ppm for obtaining the influence of toluene concentration on the toluene conversion rate. The reaction temperature was varied from 100 °C to 400 °C with an interval of 15 °C and each temperature was held for 60 min. The flow of feed gas was controlled by mass flow controller and the reaction temperature was controlled by a K-type thermocouple. The outlet gas was continuously detected by a gas chromatograph (GC-7820, Shangdong Lunan LTD) equipped with a SE-100 column and a flame ionization detector (FID). The toluene conversion was calculated using the following equation, which is applied to the full range of reaction conditions. Toluene conversion = [ T o l u e n e ] i n − [ T o l u e n e ] o u t [ T o l u e n e ] i n × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Texture structure Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of MCeO x samples. The main diffraction peaks at 2θ = 28.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.4°, 76.7° and 79.1° were the characteristic of CeO2 (JCPDS 43–1002) [13]. Some weak diffraction peaks assigned to the characteristic of CuO, Co3O4 and NiO samples. The specific peak locations and the PDF card numbers were labeled in Fig. 1. These results indicated that addition of transitional metals to CeO2 could not change the crystalline structure. Meanwhile, we calculated the cell parameter and crystal size by Scherrer's equation and Bragg's formula (Table S1). The lattice parameter was found to be smaller than CeO2 after transition metal doping into CeO2 [14]. Meanwhile, the specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of MCeO2 samples were ca. 13 m2/g, 0.04 cm3/g and 13.5 nm, respectively, as shown in Table S2. All these results illustrated that these crystalline and texture structure of all the MCeO x samples were similar. The morphology and microstructures of MCeO x were characterized by TEM images and HRTEM. As shown in Fig. 1C and E the introduction of transition metals does not significantly change the particle size and morphology of CeO2. In addition, the CoCeO x and CuCeO x exhibit a mixture state, and could not be distinguish clearly with CeO2. Thus, the lattice spacing were then conducted by HRTEM. Fig. 1D showed the HRTEM for CoCeO x , the lattice spacings of 0.165, 0.285, and 0.243 nm were assigned to the (422), (220), and (311) planes of Co3O4 (JCPDS PDF#78–1970), and the lattice spacings of 0.321 and 0.193 nm were assigned to the (111) and (220) planes of CeO2 (JCPDS PDF#34–0394), respectively [15]. Meanwhile, extra lattice spacings of 0.275 and 0.252 nm in Fig. 1F were assigned to the (110) and (−111) of CuCeO x belonging to the CuO (JCPDS PDF#72–0629), respectively [16]. The above results indicate that Cu and Co oxides have interfacial interactions with CeO2, and this causes a variation of the coordination environment in CeO2, which could trigger the spontaneous formation of charge-compensated oxygen vacancies. 3.2 Catalytic test Fig. 2 A shows the toluene conversion as a function of reaction temperature on MCeO x catalysts. All the toluene conversion curves featured an “S” type, as previously reported [17,18]. Their catalytic activities were in following order: CuCeO x ≈ CoCeO x > MnCeO x > FeCeO x > NiCeO x > ZrCeO x > CeO2. In order to quantitation compare their catalytic activity, T10 and T50 were the reaction temperature at conversion of 10 % and 50 %, as shown in Table 1 . Our previously results showed that the catalytic combustion of toluene on CeO2 followed MvK mechanism [19]. The activity and amount of surface oxygen on CeO2 was regarded as crucial factors for the catalytic combustion of toluene [2]. To further compare the activity of MCeO x , mass specific activity (MSA) and surface area specific activity (SSA) were depicted in Fig. 2B-C. The MSA of CuCeO x was ten times as large as CeO2. The SSA of CuCeO x was much larger than CeO2. All these results indicate that the transition metal doping could significantly improves the catalytic activity of CeO2. 3.3 Kinetic studies Kinetic study is a powerful tool to understand the reaction pathway via obtaining the kinetic model. Based on the kinetic results, we could obtain the key step to influence the catalytic activity, which can guide us to understanding the underlying role for the toluene combustion. For this research, CuCeO x catalyst was chosen as research object to investigate the reaction pathway, since CuCeO x showed the most activity in the all investigated catalysts. The kinetic tests modeled were similar to previous studies. Toluene conversion-reaction temperature plots and Arrhenius curves were examined for different toluene concentrations (500–4000 ppm) at 20 vol% O2, (Fig. 2B). Eight kinetic model have been established based on the power-law model, Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) model, Eley-Rideal (E-R) model and Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) model with considering the oxygen in dissociative or non-dissociative adsorption. The similar procedure have been reported in our previously work [20]. It could be found that model 7 provides the best fits the experimental data, since the slop and relative variance are closest to 1 among all the investigated kinetic model, as shown in the last two row in Fig. 3 and Table S3 [21,22]. These results indicated that the reaction pathway MCeO x proceed with the MvK mechanism. According to the MvK mechanism, it could be deduced that the oxygen of catalyst was the crucial factor for the catalytic combustion of toluene. Therefore, XPS, H2-TPR, oxygen storage capacity (OSC), oxygen release rate (ORR) and oxygen storage rate (OSR), were carried out to character the activity of oxygen on MCeO x with different transitional metal oxides. 3.4 Surface redox properties XPS was then conducted to understand the surface redox properties. Fig. 4 A peak-differentiating and imitating of the Ce 3d spectra of all catalysts revealed that Ce 3d can be categorized into eight peaks. Where U’ (904.10 eV) and V’ (885.5 eV) are attributed to Ce3+, and V0 (883.4 eV), V´’ (889.5 eV), V´´’ (898.9 eV), U0 (901.7 eV), U´’ (908.1 eV), and U´´’ (917.5 eV) are attributed to Ce4+. Thus, it is possible to estimate the condition of the catalyst defects based on the content of Ce3+ in the catalyst. It can be observed that the highest content of Ce3+ is found on the surface of CuCeO x , which was in relation with oxygen vacancies [23]. Apart from that, the transition metal doping resulted in a smaller binding energy, which was related to the formation of an interface between the transition metal and CeO2 [15]. Observing the magnitude of the binding energy shift, the order of the M-O bond energy in the M-CeO2 interface can be determined as MnCeO x > ZrCeO x > CoCeO x > FeCeO x > NiCeO x > CuCeO x [16]. Fig. 4B shows the O 1s XPS spectra of MCeO x and CeO2 catalysts. All the spectra of O 1s could be divided into three peaks centered at 529.0–529.3, 530.0–530.7 and 531.3–532 eV, which could be assigned to surface lattice oxygen (Oα), surface adsorbed oxygen species (Oβ), and physically adsorbed water (Oγ), respectively [24-28]. Note that the binding energy and amount of three oxygen species on different MCeO x catalyst were different, indicating that the addition of transition metal to CeO2 could modify the property and distribution of oxygen species. The corresponding quantitative results are shown in Table 1. Note that the proportion of Oα+ Oβ on MnCeOx, FeCeOx, CoCeOx, NiCeOx, CuCeOx and CeO2 was 80.6 %, 80.9 %, 84.7 %, 78.3 %, 83.6 % and 78.8 %, respectively, which was consisted with the order of the catalytic activity, indicating that the surface adsorbed oxygen species and surface lattice oxygen played a crucial factor for the toluene combustion based on the MvK mechanism. That probably involved more than the oxygen vacancy elevation from introducing transition metals, but also the oxygen migration from bulk lattice oxygen to surface lattice oxygen. Thus, the relationship between the proportion of Oα and Oβ and catalytic activity has been discussed in detail in the subsequent section. Fig. 5 shows H2-TPR profiles of MCeO x and CeO2 catalysts. The CeO2 showed two main reduction peaks: one peak located in the temperature region of 200–600 °C, while another peak was detected in the temperature region of 600–800 °C, which could be ascribed to the reduction of surface lattice oxygen and bulk lattice oxygen, respectively [29,30]. Addition of transition metal to CeO2 decreased the reduction temperature of surface oxygen and increased the amount of surface oxygen. However, the amount and peak temperature of the second peak ascribed to the bulk lattice oxygen decreased with addition of transition metal [31]. These results indicated that additives not only increased the activity of surface lattice oxygen and bulk lattice oxygen, but also promoted the transformation from bulk lattice oxygen and surface lattice oxygen, which was in relation with the mobility of oxygen. For the oxidation reaction, the catalytic activity was not only decided by the oxygen vacancy, but also the mobility of surface oxygen. According to Kröger-Vink notation the addition of another metal to CeO2 could generate oxygen vacancies through another elements into CeO2 [32]. The equation was as follows: (4) M O x + C e Ce x + O O x → M Ce ′ + V O + Ce O 2 Where MOx represents dopant ion, CeCe x is the lattice ceria, OO x is the lattice oxygen, MCe′ is the dopant ion in the Ce ion, VO is oxygen vacancy. The transition metal has been introduced into the CeO2 lattice in an oxidized state, which could increase the reducibility of CeO2 through lattice deformation and coordination environment variation to form uncoordinated oxygen atoms, and thus leads to the spontaneous formation of charge-compensated oxygen vacancy [33]. The variation in oxygen vacancy could be attributed to the Metal-CeO2 interface. Ion radius and M-O bond energy played an important role in oxygen vacancy. When the doped transition metal with a smaller ionic radius than the host cation, both short and long M-O bonds can be created, and the oxygen atom bound by the long bond with the metal was weaker and more easily removed [34]. The ionic radius of Ce4+, Ce3+, Mn3+, Ni2+, Co3+, and Cu2+ are 0.97 Å, 1.143 Å, 0.96 Å, 0.69 Å, 0.65 Å, and 0.73 Å, respectively. Among them, the ionic radius of Cu2+ and Co3+ are smaller, corresponding to the more oxygen vacancy and the toluene conversion ability. Meanwhile, doping transition metals can modulate the reduction of CeO2 through Metal-CeO2 interactions, which are beneficial for oxygen vacancy. Generally, the more M-O bonding energy, the stronger M-O-Ce bonds formed, which was not beneficial for the oxygen mobility [35]. Nevertheless, too low M-O bonding energy is disadvantageous in forming the Metal-CeO2 interface. Therefore, the moderate M-O bonding energy is favorable to generation of oxygen vacancies [36]. 3.5 Oxygen storage/release ability In order to understand the activity of oxygen, the OSC at different temperatures were carried out. We quantified the oxygen storage behavior by cycling oxidizing and reducing atmospheres. Table 2 shows the OSC, ORR and OSR of MCeO x samples. The OSC of CeO2 was not significantly changed when the temperature was varied from 200 to 400 °C, which was related to the active oxygen species of CeO2 being surface adsorbed oxygen. Compared with CeO2 sample, the addition of transition metal oxides to CeO2 resulted in a promotional effect on their OSC [31]. The extent of promotional effect on OSCs of MCeO x samples was in relation with transition metal oxides [37]. For MCeO x , the OSC changes in a slow and then fast trend with increasing temperature, proving that the active oxygen species of MCeO x are surface lattice oxygen and bulk phase lattice oxygen, which was in relation with the oxygen migration rate. Chemical modification of the ceria via addition of transition metal could affect the oxygen uptake and transport characteristics. In real measurement, oxygen uptakes was only a fraction of total OSC, which was dependent on the exposed surface area and oxygen mobility [10]. When the oxygen uptake is controlled by oxygen mobility, the oxygen uptake depends on temperature. Therefore, the activation energy of oxygen mobility could be obtained as follows [38]: (5) μ T = μ 0 exp ( E / RT ) Where μ is the oxygen mobility, T is the temperature and E is activation energy for oxygen uptake. Note that the oxygen storage capacity obtained in the OSC experiment under transient operating conditions could not represent the active oxygen species. In the real catalytic condition, the active oxygen species was in relation with the oxygen mobility and oxygen vacancies. OSC only represent the maximum potential oxygen vacancies. In the real system, active oxygen species was in relation with oxygen mobility. The interaction between oxygen vacancy and dopant cation resulted in a negative effect on the oxygen mobility [39]. Thus, manipulation with dopant cation would be a good strategy to obtain optimum dopant and ratio. Table S3 shows the oxygen uptake as a function of temperature. For CeO2 sample, the OSC remained the similar during all the investigated temperature, indicating that the oxygen mobility in the CeO2 was negligence and only surface oxygen species (surface adsorbed oxygen species) were active oxygen species. For MnCeO x and NiCeO x samples, the OSC firstly remained the same and then increased with increasing the temperature. The surface adsorbed oxygen and surface lattice oxygen were the main active oxygen species at the 200–250 °C. With further increasing the temperature, the bulk lattice oxygen was extra active oxygen species. Note that the initial temperature for increase of OSC could represent the ability of the mobility of bulk lattice oxygen mobility. However, for CuCeO x sample, the OSC increased gradually from 0.406 mmol·g −1 to 1.025 mmol·g −1, when the temperature was shifted from 200 to 400 °C. The similar phenomenon was observed on the Fe and Co dopant cations. These results indicated that the oxygen uptake on these samples was controlled by the oxygen mobility. Thus, the Eq. (4) can be expressed in terms of oxygen uptake. (6) NT = μ 0 exp ( E / RT ) Where N represent the OSC. The activation energy of bulk lattice oxygen mobility could be calculated based on the Eq. (6). The Ea-Oxygen of CuCeO x , CoCeO x and FeCeO x were 18.5, 26.0 and 12.2 kJ/mol, respectively. Combining the Ea-Oxygen and OSC of CeO2 and MCeO x catalysts, it could be deduced that the addition of transition metal could not only affect the property of surface adsorbed and surface lattice oxygen, but also the mobility of bulk lattice oxygen. These promotional effect in two aspects induced different roles on the catalytic combustion of toluene. Transition metal introduction can effectively improve the oxygen uptake of CeO2. At lower temperatures, the oxygen uptake occurs only in a thin shell near the external surface of individual support particles in their state of aggregation. Hence, the improvement of oxygen uptake at low temperatures with transition metals introduced to CeO2 was related to the surface oxygen (including surface adsorbed oxygen and surface lattice oxygen). At higher temperatures, the oxygen mobility was fairly large and the oxygen uptake can occur in a wide shell close to the center of the individual support particles. Thus, the promotion of oxygen uptake at high temperatures was related to bulk-phase lattice oxygen and oxygen mobility rate [10]. The dopant ion owned two roles on the oxidation of toluene: (1) substitution of dopant ion in the Ce4+ site increase the reducibility of Ce4+, (2) the reducible nature of the dopant ion provided additional redox couples [3]. The transition metal dopant could improve the catalytic effect of toluene oxidation by decreasing the activation energy for oxygen vacancy diffusion and improving the migration capacity of bulk lattice oxygen. Correlating OSC with catalytic activity, OSC was found to be linearly related to T10 (Fig. 6 ). For CeO2, the oxygen uptake is mainly derived from surface lattice oxygen and surface adsorbed oxygen. For MCeO x , in addition to surface oxygen, the rate of oxygen mobility is also an important factor in oxygen uptake. Therefore, the comprehensive effect between surface lattice oxygen and oxygen mobility could affect the catalytic activity. 3.6 Diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy study In order to understanding the absorption species on the surface and the catalytic reaction pathways of CeO x after transition metal deposition, in situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) experiments were performed over the CuCeO x . According to our study, CuCeOx catalyzed toluene combustion following the MvK mechanism, the toluene first reacted with the oxygen of the catalyst. Thus, only the toluene was added to the feed gas to investigate the first step of the MvK mechanism. Fig. 7 shows the in situ DRIFTS of toluene infused with 1000 ppm + Ar in the presence of CuCeO x catalyst for 40 min. The bands at 1733, 1652 and 1648 cm−1 could be assigned to aldehyde species [40,41]. The band at 1749 cm−1 was ascribed to anhydride species [42]. The band at 1717 cm−1 was considered to be the C = O vibration peaks of ketones [43]. The bands at 1508 and 1496 cm−1 were attributed to the asymmetric C–C stretching vibration of aromatic ring [44]. The bands at 1363 and 1473 cm−1 were associated with the CH– symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of the CH3– Group [45]. The bands at 1540 1395 and 1338 cm−1 was assigned to typical benzoate species [46,47]. The above results indicated that in the absence of molecular oxygen, the toluene was oxidized to produce aldehyde species, anhydride species and ketones. All these adsorbed species are summarized in Table 3 . As shown in Fig. 7, when toluene was introduced, typical C–C stretching vibrations of aromatic rings were immediately observed at 1508 and 1496 cm−1. The characteristic peaks of symmetric and asymmetric deformation vibration of C–H on CH3– group also appeared at 1363 and 1473 cm−1, which indicated the adsorption of toluene molecules. The peaks intensities at 1733, 1652 and 1648 cm−1 were continuously enhanced as shown in Fig. 7A, indicating the continuous production of benzaldehyde substances. In the meanwhile, the C = O vibration peak of ketones (1717 cm−1) and the correlation peak of anhydride species (1749 cm−1) appeared as well. The bands of benzoates at 1540, 1395 and 1338 cm−1 appeared and continued to increase, and the peak at 1540 cm−1 became the main peak, indicating that benzoin was an important intermediate species. With this information, some key intermediates in the catalytic oxidation of toluene could be preliminarily judged. As shown in Fig. 8 , the intensity of all intermediate species characteristic peaks reached a maximum at 10 min, followed by a weak decrease, and finally reached stability. Before 10 min of toluene, all the intermediate species accumulated over time. After 10 min, these intermediate species were consumed to generate CO2 and H2O which resulted in a slight decrease in band intensity. When the reaction continued, the adsorbed species on the catalyst surface reach equilibrium. These results indicated that the toluene could reacted with the oxygen of catalyst to form aldehyde, ketones and benzoate species, which was consist with the MvK mechanism. 3.7 Mechanism aspects The kinetic studies and DRIFTS results indicated that the reaction on MCeO x proceeced via MvK mechanism. It could be deduced that the oxygen of catalyst was crucial for the catalytic combustion of toluene. The linear relationship between OSC and catalytic activity revealed that the addition of different transitional metals caused different effects on active oxygen species in CeO2. The introduction of transition metals provides extra oxygen vacancies in CeO2 via Kröger-Vink notation, meanwhile affects the rate of oxygen mobility from the bulk phase to replenish the surface lattice. The different ionic radius and M-O bond energy of the transition metals lead to different oxygen storage and migration of MCeO x , enabling MCeO x to exhibit differences in catalytic activity. Specifically, transition metal doping with a smaller ionic radius and moderate M-O bonding energy is more favorable for catalyst oxygen migration, thus exhibiting high activity for the toluene catalytic combustion. 4 Conclusions In this work, the addition of transition to CeO2 was investigated on the catalytic combustion of toluene. It was found that the order of catalytic activity of MCeO x was as follows: CuCeO x ≈ CoCeO x > MnCeO x > FeCeO x > NiCeO x > ZrCeO x > CeO2. Kinetic studies showed that CuCeO x proceed via MvK mechanism with non-dissociative adsorption of oxygen. The addition of transition metal to CeO2 played two roles on the oxygen storage capacity: (1) providing extra oxygen sites via Kröger-Vink notation, (2) the increase of the oxygen mobility. The linear relationship was observed on the OSC and catalytic activity in the real reaction conditions. These results provided a new strategies for the development of superior catalyst for catalytic combustion of VOCs. coredata.dc:description: CeO2 with varied doping transition metal was investigated to understand the oxygen storage capacity and oxygen release property of CeO2-based catalysts for toluene combustion. The order of catalytic activity was as follows: CuCeO x ≈ CoCeO x > MnCeO x > FeCeO x > NiCeO x > ZrCeO x > CeO2. Kinetic studies showed that the reaction on CuCeO x proceed via an MvK mechanism and the oxygen of catalyst was crucial factor for the toluene combustion. H2-TPR and XPS showed the addition of transition metal to CeO2 could modify the surface lattice oxygen. Moreover, the oxygen storage capacity and oxygen release properties showed the transition metal additive not only change the amount of oxygen, but also affect the oxygen mobility. A linear relationship was observed between the catalytic activity and oxygen storage capacity. Diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy showed the toluene first adsorbed on the surface of catalyst, and then reacted with oxygen of catalyst to form benzyl, benzoate and benzyl carbonate species. All these results provided a new strategy to develop high performance catalyst.
